description: The UK’s oldest brewery site, home to Young’s for almost 200 years. Architect's talk covers planning, redevelopment, design and materiality, and includes the new public square, boulevard, riverwalk, new buildings & restored listed buildings. There will also be a guided tour of our on-site Heritage Centre, which displays many historical artefacts and tells the story of the site's brewing history.

factsheet.heading: Project Overview
paragraphs: Ram Quarter is a residential-led mixed-use masterplan, developed by Greenland UK, and has transformed the historic Young’s brewery site into a new urban quarter. The development celebrates the strong heritage of the Ram Brewery buildings and creates a vibrant new heart in Wandsworth town centre.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Beer has been produced on the site since at least 1533, making it the oldest continuously operating brewery in the UK. Following Young’s closure in 2006, a small-scale brewery was maintained on site during the construction period to ensure that the development retained its historic legacy. The original Grade II* listed brewery complex is now home to a new brewery, a Heritage Centre, premises occupied by other independent retailers (e.g. a restaurant and southwest London's only bowling alley), and exclusive loft-style residential apartments.

factsheet.heading: Scheme
paragraphs: The listed buildings have been carefully integrated into the Ram Quarter masterplan, which was conceived as a series of interlinked public urban spaces and with the previously inaccessible riverfront of the River Wandle now featuring enhanced biodiversity, planted terraces, footpaths and a new pedestrian bridge.

Ten lower-level buildings adopt and reinterpret the materials, forms and scale of the existing industrial structures to define the urban edges of the public realm. At ground level, the elevations are enlivened with retail units to create a vibrant and active environment, whilst above, the high-quality residential accommodation benefits from the more tranquil setting of private roof gardens.

factsheet.heading: Materiality
paragraphs: EPR’s design uses a restricted palette of materials: brick for the façades, and copper or zinc for the roofs. This selection is a response to the character of the conservation area and the historic use of these materials within the old brewery.

factsheet.heading: Heritage Centre
paragraphs: Ram Quarter is the site of the UK's oldest continuously-operating brewery: records date back to at least 1533, although brewing almost certainly pre-dates that.  The development's Heritage Centre contains many fascinating artefacts from the site's history.  The site also houses a pair of magnificent early Victorian beam engines, the oldest of their type anywhere in the world still in their original location and never having been out of working condition.  Each Open House tour will conclude with a free visit to the Heritage Centre for the first fifteen people who register.
